turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Hi, Naomi, it's Joel.

turns.speaker: NAOMI'S VOICE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: How's it going?

turns.speaker: NAOMI'S VOICE
turns.text: Good. I called you at work today. They said you were home sick.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I know. I had to take the day to think.

turns.speaker: NAOMI'S VOICE
turns.text: Yeah, I tried you at home. Did you get my message?

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I just got in.

turns.speaker: NAOMI'S VOICE
turns.text: Long day thinking.

turns.speaker: NAOMI'S VOICE
turns.text: That's me.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: There you are.  Naomi, it's just... I'm afraid if we fall back into this fast without considering the problems we had...

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: It was snowing.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: There are two of them. Couldn't make them out. The orange glow of a cigarette.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: The driver waved. So casual, friendly.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: I'm like a joke to them.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I might be making a mistake.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: Maybe I'm making a mistake. Maybe I just need to learn to live with this. First of all, I'll get over it. Secondly, it happened. Those who do not remember history are condemned to repeat it. Who said that? Churchill? I'm not sure. But I don't care. She did it to me. I have to rid myself of this. Fuck her.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Fuck you, Clementine.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Pink.  There was a number on it. I remember. AL 1718?  I have to follow through with this. I have no choice.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: The pill was pink, I remember. It had some letters and numbers on it. What were they? AL 1718? AL something. Four digits. I don't like taking pills when I don't know what they are. I have no choice.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: It's them.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: It's too late.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I should maybe talk to you.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: Clementine. I should just maybe talk to her.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I love you and if you knew that... if I told you what happened... I'll explain everything, what we meant to each other. I'll tell you everything about our time together. You'll know everything again and...

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: Maybe if I just explain what happened, I wouldn't have to go through this and I could tell you everything and it would be like you knew and we could rebuild and we could be happy again and...

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Clementine.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: That's your look for me.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Gotta get home. How could she do this to me? How could she not care about what we meant to each other. What a fuck! What a fucking monster she is!

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: Oh, God. I miss her. I can't believe she's with that guy now! I'm never going to see her again. I love her so much. What a fucking monster she is!

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: So then she just stops calling.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: I wasn't going to call her. Not after the way she was.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Any messages, Carmen?

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: Right! She called me an old lady here, too! And I remember, I said...

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: And what are you like? A wino?

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: How's the chicken?

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: Is that like us? Are we just bored with each other?

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: She's so sexy.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I loved you on this day. I love this memory. The rain. Us just hanging.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I can't. I have to go home. I'll do it later.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: I didn't want to do this. But I had to or they would've called me a girl.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Naomi.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: On the couch. Dark. Quiet. I wondered if I had made a terrible mistake. I almost reached for the phone about a thousand times. I thought I could take it back, erase it, explain I had momentarily lost my mind. Then I told myself we weren't happy. That was the truth. That what we were was safe. It was unfair to you and to me to stay in a relationship for that reason. I thought about Clementine and the spark when I was with her, but then I thought what you and I had was real and adult and therefore significant even if it wasn't much fun. But I wanted fun. I saw other people having fun and I wanted it. Then I thought fun is a lie, that no one is really having fun; I'm being suckered by advertising and movie bullshit... then I thought maybe not, maybe not. And then I thought, as I always do at this point in my argument, about dying.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Okay. I wish you could come.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: This is it. The night we met. My God, it's over.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Your back to me. In that orange sweatshirt I would come to know so well and even hate eventually. At the time I thought, how cool, an orange sweatshirt.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: I remember being drawn to you even then. I thought, I love this woman because she's alone down there looking out at the black ocean.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: But I went back to my food. The next thing I remember, I felt someone sitting next to me and I saw the orange sleeve out of the corner of my eye.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: So you're still on the Zoloft?

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: Next thing I remember we were walking down near the surf.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Clementine.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: I couldn't believe you did that. I was paralyzed with fear.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I really should go. I really need to catch my ride.

turns.speaker: VOICE-OVER
turns.text: I didn't want to go. I was too nervous. I thought, maybe you were a nut. But you were exciting. You called from upstairs.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: We'll start with your most recent memories and go backwards -- There is an emotional core to each of our memories -- As we eradicate this core, it starts its degradation process -- By the time you wake up in the morning, all memories we've targeted will have withered and disappeared. Like a dream upon waking.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Is there any sort of risk of brain damage?

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Well, technically, the procedure itself is brain damage, but on a par with a night of heavy drinking. Nothing you'll miss.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: I'm sorry you saw one of our notification cards. You never should have.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Well... I did.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: We can help you through this. Why don't you start now by telling me everything you can remember about your relationship with Clementine.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: It was a mess. I don't know how it got this way...

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: We can help you through this. Why don't you start now by telling me everything you can remember about --

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: You have to stop this!

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: What? What do you mean?

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I'm trapped in my head and everything I love is being erased! Stop it now!

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Yes, but... I'm just something you're imagining. What can I do? I'm in your head, too.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Yours?

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: You take it. I don't know.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Naomi, I really value our relationship. I hope it's possible for us to stay in touch.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Don't do this to me now, Joel. Really.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: So what's going on, Joel?

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I don't know, I've just been thinking, maybe we're not happy with each other.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Y'know, we've been, I don't know, sort of, unhappy with each other and --

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Don't say "we" when you mean "you."

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I think maybe, we're both so used to operating at this level that -- How can one person be unhappy? If one person is unhappy, both have to be... by definition.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Bullshit. Who is it? You met someone.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: No. I just need some space, maybe.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: The thing is, Joel, whatever it is you think you have with this chick, once the thrill wears off, you're just going to be Joel with the same fucking problems.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: It's not somebody else.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: How was it?

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: You didn't miss much. Rob and Carrie say hello.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Hi, Rob and Carrie.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Go back to sleep.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Yeah. Come to bed. I'm cold.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: In a minute.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: So you don't mind?

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: I've got to finish this chapter anyway.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Say hi to Rob and Carrie. Have some fun!

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I hope you get your work done.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: So... you haven't been involved with anyone in all this time?

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: It's been a pretty lonely couple of years.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Well, it was my fault -- the break- up. I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Oh, sweetie. It really does cut both ways. We were taking each other for granted and --

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I miss you.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Miss you, too.  I have been seeing someone for a little while.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: Oh! Great. That's great!

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: A religion instructor at Columbia. A good guy. He's a good guy.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I'm sorry. I really shouldn't have --

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: I'm glad you called.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: So you think the dissertation will get published?

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: I don't know. I'm not sure there's a big public demand for books on Calvinism and Misogyny.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: Okay, Joel. I suppose you're right.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: I had a good time last night. I really did.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: So I'm going to get some sleep. I'm glad you're okay.

turns.speaker: JOEL
turns.text: We'll speak soon.

turns.speaker: NAOMI
turns.text: 'Night.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, hey, Patrick.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Hi, Mary. How's it going?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, Patrick, you didn't want any, did you?

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Nah, I don't know.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I love quotes. So did Winston Churchill. He actually has a quotation in Bartlett's about Bartlett's. Isn't that trippy?

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Yeah. Cool.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: "The quotations when engraved upon the memory give you good thoughts."

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Very cool. Trippy.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I like to read what smart people say. So many beautiful, important things.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Definitely!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I think he'll be in Bartlett's one day.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Boo.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Stan... c'mon...

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Sorry. I just --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's just... y'know... I mean...

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I know. Anyway --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Anyway, I've got to do my tap dance here.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: See you later, alligator.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: 'kay.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Hey, if you're ordering lunch for Mierzwiak, would you --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I better do this, Stan.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's freezing out.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You found us okay?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yeah.  Poor guy.  Have anything to drink?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: We haven't checked.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well, allow me to do the honors. It's fucking freezing and I need something.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Nietzsche. Beyond Good and Evil. Found it my Bartletts.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: That's a good one.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yeah, I can't wait to tell Howard! It seems really appropriate.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: It's a good one all right.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Yup.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't you think Howard's like that? Smart? Important?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Yup.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Let him go, Stan. I can help.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Go.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's amazing, isn't it? Such a gift Howard gave the world.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: To let people begin again. It's beautiful. You look at a baby and it's so fresh, so clean, so free. And adults... they're like this messy tangle of anger and phobias and sadness... hopelessness. And Howard just makes it go away.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You love him, don't you?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: It's stopped.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Listen, it's not erasing.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: It's not erasing. He's off the screen.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I don't know. He's not on the map.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I don't know what to do! I don't know what to do! Crap. Crap...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well, what should we do?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I don't know! I just said that!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sor-ry  We have to do something. He can't wake up half done.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Shit!

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: No way. I can handle this.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: This guy's only half cooked. There's no time to fuck around, Stan.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He's coming?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You better go.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Hell no.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Hey.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Do you swear you didn't know?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I swear.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: And you never even suspected? Never saw us behaving in any unusual way together?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Once, maybe.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: It was here. At his car. I was coming back from a job and spotted you together. You seemed caught. I waved. You giggled.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: How did I look?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Happy. Happy with a secret.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: And after that?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I never saw you together like that again. So I figured I was imagining things.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I really like you, Mary. You know that.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Do you remember anything else? What I was wearing? Was I standing close to him? Was I leaning against his car like I owned it? How did he look at me when I giggled? Tell me everything.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You were in red. That red sweater with the little flowers, I think. You were leaning against his car.  He looked a little like a kid. Kind of goofy and wide-eyed. I'd never seen him look like that before. Happy. You looked beautiful. You looked in love.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thanks, Stan.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What do you want, Stan?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Can I... I brought some --

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I know what it is.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Then why did you ask me?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I don't know. I just -- there are a lot of really confused people showing up at the office.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: They have a right to know. Howard is a thief. He steals the truth.  I can't remember my baby! I can't remember my baby. It existed and I can't even remember. Do you understand that?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Mary, people come to him voluntarily.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I won't allow it. Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it. What do you think of that? That's from my quote book.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: The office is filled with people who want their memories re-erased.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Remember the Alamo! Remember the Alamo!

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Mary... please. This is hurting people.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Howard, your one o'clock.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Thanks, Mary. You can bring her in.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Mary...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Order me a pastrami for after?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Cole slaw, ice tea?

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Welcome, Howard.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Okay, we're back in.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That was beautiful to watch, Howard. Like a surgeon or a concert pianist.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Well, thank you, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Do you like quotes, Howard?

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: How do you mean?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, um, like famous quotes. I find reading them inspirational to me. And in my reading I've come across some I thought you might like, too.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Oh. Well, I'd love to hear some.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Okay, um, there's one that goes "Blessed are the forgetful, for they get the better even of their blunders."

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Is that Nietzsche?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yeah, yeah it is, Howard. And here I was thinking I could tell you something you didn't know.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: It's a good quote, Mary. I'm glad we both know it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: There's another one I like, I read. It's by Pope Alexander.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Alexander Pope?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes, shit. Oops, sorry!  Sorry. It's just I told myself I wasn't going to say Pope Alexander and sound like a dope and then I go ahead and do it. Like I psyched myself out.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: It's no big deal.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You are such a sweetheart.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: That's lovely.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Really? I thought it was appropriate maybe. That's all.  I really admire the work that you do. I know it's not proper to be so familiar but I guess since we're outside the workplace I feel a certain liberty to --

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: It's fine, Mary. I'm happy to hear it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Okay. Good. Great. Thanks.  I like you, Howard... an awful lot. Is that terrible?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I've loved you for a very long time. I'm sorry! I shouldn't have said that.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: I've got a wife, Mary. Kids. You know that.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I wish I was your wife. I wish I had your kids.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: We can't do this.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No you're right. Once again. You're a decent man, Howard.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What, Howard?

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: We... have a history. I'm sorry. You wanted the procedure. You wanted it done... to get past. I have to finish in there. It's almost morning. We'll talk later.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thanks.  So... do we talk about this... or what?

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: I don't know what I'm supposed say, Mary. I want to do the right thing here.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Do you love me? Did you love me? Something. I listened to my tape. I can't believe I've been sitting right in front of it for a year. It's like listening to someone else's story. I mean, I hear myself talking about having sex with you and I can't even imagine you naked. I can't even say "naked" to you!

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: I have a family, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You made me have an abortion.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: It was a mutual decision.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You made me have you erased! I loved you. I love you! How could you --

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: I didn't make you. You thought it best.  But, look, I take full responsibility.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Stan? What's going on?

turns.speaker: STAN'S VOICE
turns.text: The guy we're doing? He's disappeared from the map. I can't find him anywhere.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Okay, what happened right before he disappeared?

turns.speaker: STAN'S VOICE
turns.text: I was away from the monitor for a second. I had it on automatic. I had to go pee.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Well, where was Patrick?

turns.speaker: STAN'S VOICE
turns.text: He went home sick.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Jesus. All right, what's the address.

turns.speaker: STAN'S VOICE
turns.text: 1062 Sherman Drive. Apartment 1E, Rockville Center.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Ah, your journal. This will be invaluable.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: December 15th, 2004. I met someone tonight. Oh, Christ: I don't know what to do. Her name is Clementine and she's amazing. So alive and spontaneous and passionate and sensitive. Things with Naomi and I have been stagnant for so long.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Mary. What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: She came to help, Howard.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I tried that already.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Did you try going through C-Gate?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Yeah. Of course.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You get some sleep, Howard. I'll take it from here.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Yeah, probably a good idea.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Howard, they've disappeared again.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Oh dear.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I'll go out for a smoke. If no one minds.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: That's fine, Stan.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: So, I've got to drop the van off.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Thanks, Stan. Thanks.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: She should not have done this, Stan. As mad as she was... as justifiably --

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about, Howard.

turns.speaker: MIERZWIAK
turns.text: Mary has stolen our files and is sending them back to people.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
turns.text: Oh, hi.

turns.speaker: OLD WOMAN
turns.text: Hi, I was in the neighborhood and thought I'd see --

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
turns.text: I think he's in a conference. Unfortunately. I'm really sorry.

turns.speaker: OLD WOMAN
turns.text: Would you just try him? You never know. As long as I'm here. You never know.

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
turns.text: Of course. Please have a seat.

turns.speaker: OLD WOMAN
turns.text: This book -- It's essential that people read it because --  -- It's the truth. And only I know it.

turns.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
turns.text: Maybe after the holidays then.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: The voltage looks fine.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Then check the connections.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Does that help?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Yeah, that looks better. Thanks.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: It's an apartment.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Not a dump, then, but kind of plain. Uninspired. And there's a stale smell. Sort of stuffy. I don't know. Stuffy.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Patrick, let's just get through this. We have a long night ahead of us.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Just wanted to let you know.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: I like Mary. I like when she comes to visit. I just don't think she likes me.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: She likes you okay.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: I wonder if I should invite my girlfriend over, too. I have a girlfriend now.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You can if you want.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Did I tell you I have a new girlfriend?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: This one's history. Moving on...

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: The thing is... my situation is a little weird. My girlfriend situation.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Patrick, we need to focus.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: I gotta tell you something. I kind of fell in love with her last night.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: She was unconscious, Patrick.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: She was beautiful. So sweet and funky and voluptuous. I kind of stole a pair of her panties, is what.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Jesus, Patrick!

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Mary hates me. I've never been popular with the ladies.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Maybe if you stopped stealing their panties.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Okay, There's more, Stan --

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: What's your bartlett's?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: It's a quote book.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Hold on. Let me ask my friend.  Stan, can I leave for a little while? My girlfriend is very --

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Patrick, we're in the middle of --

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: She's right in the neighborhood. She's upset.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I can handle it. He's pretty much on auto-pilot anyway.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Thanks, Stan. I owe you.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: I'm a friend of Bonanza Jellybean's.

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: I know who you are.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Oh? Well, there's been some trouble on the ranch. I came up here to get out of the way. It's so dark now I doubt if I could find my way back down. If you could help...

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: Save your breath for the climb.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: But I don't know how to polka.

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: Neither do I... ha ha ho ho hee hee.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: Clockworks.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Clockworks?

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: The Clockworks is one reason that I am here on Siwash Ridge. I accepted the invitation to be initiated as a shaman by an aged Siwash chief who was the principle outside confederate of the Clock People.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Siwash, huh?

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: He was a degenerated warlock who could turn urine into beer, and the honor that he extended me gave me rights of occupancy in this sacred cave on this far-away Siwash Ridge. I came to the Dakota hills to construct a clockworks of my own.

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: But unlike the clockworks of the Clock People, my ticks more accurately echo the ticks of the universe....  ......ha ha ho ho and hee hee.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: The Clock People?

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: During the Second World War I busted out of Tule Lake detention camp; as a Japanese-American, I had been put there and watched over. I found refuge with the Clock People, who discovered me in a snow bank, near dead, I had been climbing across the Sierra Nevada mountains.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Then if you are Japanese, then why are you called the Chink?

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: The Clock People mistook me for Chinese. And the name stuck. In the same way that all Indian tribes came to be labeled "Indians" through the ignorance of an Italian sailor with a taste for oranges, it is only fitting that "Indians" misnamed me. The Clock People, however, are not a tribe, rather they are a gathering of Indians from various tribes. They have lived together since 1906.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: What do you believe in then?

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: Ha ha ho ho and hee hee.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Is everything getting worse?

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: Yes, everything is getting worse. But everything is also getting better.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: The Countess has come to our aid. The Rubber Rose Ranch is officially deeded to all the cowgirls. And I have been asked to oversee the ranch. For $300 a week. And as it turns out, the Countess is not going to be the vegetable the doctors thought he was... here's a picture!

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: I want to go back to the Clock People. I kind of miss those fool redskins and wonder what they're up to. What's happened to Jelly?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: She had a one way-ticket to Kansas City.

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: You mean she's dead?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: But that's an old story now...... I can't believe that you would leave the Butte.

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: Easy come, easy go.
